abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Water and Wastewater
            Project in Russia, aims to arrest the decline of water, and
            wastewater services in fourteen medium-size cities.
            Regardless of its beneficial environmental effects in the
            long-run, adversity is nonetheless expected to occur during
            construction, due to inappropriate disposal of excavation
            materials, construction debris, and small amounts of
            hazardous wastes and materials, in addition to noise
            disturbances, dusting, and traffic disruption. This
            environmental assessment reviews each project city
            separately, and provides an environmental baseline.
            Mitigation is largely addressed in the procurement
            documents, which include contract clauses for safe keeping,
            in and around construction sites, to minimize dusting
            through the use of sprinklers, to limit construction to
            day-time working schedules only, minimizing noise
            disturbances, and to restore vegetation following
            construction, subject to inspection, and compliance with the
            Russian Law on Environmental Expertise. Sludge deposits, and
            effluents, particularly in the city of Gagarin, contain
            critical concentrations of phosphorus, and nitrogen
            compounds, such as ammonia and nitrate, which should be
            treated by process-integrated measures, and sludge treatment
            systems. By and large, components with significant adverse
            environmental impacts (construction budget of over $0.5
            million) shall be subject to review by the Department of
            State Ecological Expertise, to ensure compliance with
            environmental legislation.
